topicv3: Agricultural Supply Chain m1325993 194,Agricultural Risk and Security m1327607 1967,Agriculture and Food Security m1326205 435,Food Security m1326439 199,Linking Farmers with Markets m1325991 1959

abstracts.cdata!:
The Accelerated Food Security Project
            for Tanzania contributed to higher food production and
            productivity in targeted areas by improving farmers'
            access to critical agricultural inputs. The outcome of the
            project was rated moderately satisfactory with the Bank
            performing moderately satisfactory and the Borrower
            performing moderately unsatisfactory. The overall risk to
            development was rated substantial. The project had several
            monitering and evaluation shortcomings. Therefore, data
            quality is poor. Although only one indicator (maize yield
            achieved by farmers with subsidized seed and fertilizer) out
            of the six project developmetn objective level indicators
            was fully achieved, the project made significant progress on
            most of its targets. Four key lessons were learned from the
            implementation of this project. Firstly, successful
            implementation of emergency operations significantly
            benefits from careful advance planning, especially
            procurement. Secondly, mainstreaming projects in line
            ministries works best when complemented by pragmatic
            solutions to implementation issues as they arise. Thirdly,
            agricultural input voucher programs can significantly
            increase productivity, but remain difficult to administer.
            Lastly, a final lesson learned is that inclusion of major
            civil works (e.g., the irrigation infrastructure) without
            expedited procurement arrangements, while well meaning, may
            not be best suited for these type of emergency operations.
            Such longer gestation investments could divert focus and
            contribute to implementation delays.
